What does “The Bear” tell us about leadership and team dynamics? It seems like everybody has been talking about the FX-produced TV show "The Bear”. The great story telling reveals raw emotion, complex characters, a lot of swearing, and anxiety-inducing moments that resonate with real-life experiences. * Kitchen dynamics as a microcosm The fast-paced kitchen setting mirrors real-world team dynamics. By observing collaboration, conflict, and friendship, we gain insights into (effective or not so effective) teamwork. * Seeing beyond first impressions The characters often surprise us by revealing hidden depths, especially in Season 3. As leaders, we should look beyond initial judgments and recognize people’s multifaceted nature. * Balancing authenticity and conformity Teams often struggle with individuality versus alignment. Empathic leaders encourage self-expression while focusing on a shared purpose. * Change and alignment Change is uncomfortable, yet oftentimes essential. Leaders can guide teams through transitions by addressing concerns first. You can observe what happens when a leader fails to listen and communicate well. * Transparency and vulnerability Syd disrupts norms but builds trust through openness. It’s no secret that leaders who embrace vulnerability create an environment for stronger connections. “The Bear” really challenged me to sit with the discomfort. Also to observe and reflect on my own leadership practices, and to appreciate the dance of group dynamics. Without spoiling the plot – what are your favorite moments of the show? #leadership #groupdynamics #empathicleadership #growthmindset

A Tubi survey of 5,000 Americans who stream found when it comes to streaming and romance in real life, nearly six in 10 people polled across all 50 states consider streaming a movie or series and hooking up as an acceptable first date.. ⤵️ The survey also found: ▶️ The average person reportedly streams 1,112 hours of content a year. ▶️ Wyoming was the most likely state to stream more than 50 hours per week. ▶️ Nevadans stream the most TV shows or movies: 40% are watching more than 10. ▶️ True crime is the most popular genre in Minnesota ▶️ Indiana is all about dramas, 48% named it as their favorite genre to stream. Read more findings & state comparisons here: https://hubs.ly/Q028tcQs0 #streaming #statebystate #opinionpoll

Can you actually divide up a movie and call it an “original series”? FYI - What you’re looking at is actually the 2008 film “Australia” which Hulu has divided up into five episodes. Is something that we will continue to see more of on streaming services? Is this a short term trend that is the result of the writers’ and actors’ strike this year? Or a longer term one in response to the wider audiences’ shortened attention spans? And if so, what could this tell us about successfully craft our own work? How would you successfully divide & rename up a classic film like “Lawrence of Arabia” for example?
